College of Chemical Engineering Xiangtan University Xiangtan 411105 China Graphical abstract The selective hydrogenation of furfural derived from biomass is of significant importance in the synthesis of valuable chemical compounds. In this work, Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts with varying metal ratios were effectively synthesized using the urea deposition method and employed in catalytic hydrogenation of furfural (FA) to furfuryl alcohol (FOL) and cyclopentanone (CPO) in different solvents. The study revealed that the synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni favors the formation of CuNi alloys, thereby facilitating the reduction of CuO and NiO and resulting in larger amount of metallic species (Cu0/+ and Ni0), and promoting the formation of highly dispersed nanoparticles. Moreover, the formed Cu+ species can serve as Lewis acid sites and improve the adsorption of polarized C = O, thus significantly enhancing the selectivity to FOL. More importantly, the cooperation between Cu+ species and water can promote the aqueous-phase hydrogenation-rearrangement (AP-HR) of FA to CPO. Also, in-situ/on-line DRIFTS shows that Cu3Ni1/SiO2 preferentially adsorbs and activates C = O and prefers to form 4-hydroxy-2-cyclopentenone (HCP), which is the key intermediate to form CPO. DFT calculations agree with the in-situ/on-line DRIFTS, showing that Cu3Ni1 (111) crystal surface with the lowest d-band center and the strongest electronic effects presents the highest adsorption energies of H2, H2O, and FA, the lowest adsorption energies of H*, FOL, and CPO, and the lowest energy barriers of Piancatelli rearrangement of FOL to HCP. Under the optimum conditions, Cu3Ni1/SiO2 gives 99.9 % yield to FOL at 333 K in isopropanol and 96.7 % yield to CPO at 413 K in water. The low cost and high activity of Cu3Ni1/SiO2 make it a potential catalyst for the green production of FOL and CPO in industry. Keywords Selective furfural hydrogenation Cu-Ni bimetallic catalyst Cu+ species Structure-activity relationship DFT calculations Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Global fossil fuel resources are limited, while excessive consumption of fossil fuel will emit large amounts of CO2 (greenhouse gases) and other polluting gases (such as N and S oxides), resulting in global warming and environmental pollution. Using abundant renewable biomass resources to produce liquid fuels and high value-added chemicals has become the focus of research in the field of sustainable chemistry and new energy [1]. Lignocellulose is the most abundant biomass resource to synthesize many oxygen-containing organic molecules through catalytic transformations, which can be used as feedstocks for the synthesis of liquid fuels and fine chemicals [2]. Catalytic hydrogenation of oxygen-containing organic molecules is one of the key technologies for bio-fuels and fine chemicals production [3]. As a crucial biology-based platform molecule derived from lignocellulose, FA has attracted wide attention due to its active chemical properties and easy access [4]. As shown in Scheme 1 , FA contains unsaturated C = O and furan rings, which can be further converted into a series of high-value chemicals via hydrogenation, ring opening, and rearrangement, such as FOL [5], Furan [6], 2-methyl furan (2-MF) [7], tetrahydrofuryl alcohol (THFOL) [8], Tetrahydrofurfural (THF) [9], 2-methyl tetrahydrofuran (THMF) [10], and CPO [11] etc. Among these chemicals, FOL accounts for up to 62 % and is an important monomer in the synthesis of furan resin, synthetic fiber, rubber, lubricant, vitamin C, lysine, etc [5]. Specially, CPO is an important chemical raw material and is widely used in the synthesis of fungicides, perfume chemicals, solvents, synthetic rubber, and pharmaceuticals [11]. Its traditional preparation methods mainly include high-temperature pyrolysis of adipic acid and its derivatives and cyclopentene oxidation [12]. However, these raw materials come from limited fossil resources, with high cost and low yield. Therefore, the AP-HR of FA to CPO is more promising and in line with the concept of sustainable development and green chemistry. The AP-HR of FA to CPO can be easily realized over noble-metal catalysts such as Pt [13,14], Ru [15], Au [16], and Pd [17–19] under mild conditions. Hronec first reported an entirely new route for the selective hydrogenation of FA to CPO over 5 % Pt/C in water with 76.5 % yield to CPO at 433 K [13]. After that, Liu [14] prepared the biomass-derived porous heteroatom doped carbon-supported Pt catalyst (Pt/NC-BS-800) and used it in FA hydrogenation in water, it was found that carbonization temperature could effectively adjust the surface property of the catalyst and then determined the selectivity to CPO. It is widely accepted that metal catalysts with rich Lewis acidity favor the C = O hydrogenation and hydrolysis in hydrogenation ring rearrangement reactions [17–19]. Li [17] reported that the double-metal cyanide (DMC) supported Pd (Pd/FeZn-DMC) catalyst with a moderate Lewis acidity gave the highest yield of 96.6 % to CPO. Subsequently, their team [18] found that the Lewis acidity of pyrochlore-supported Pd catalysts (A2B2O7) could be tuned by the substitution of A and B site metals, and the Pd/Y2Sn2O7 with the strongest Lewis acidity exhibited the highest yield to CPO (95.0 %). Despite the good progress of noble-metal catalysts, their scarcity and high price greatly limit large-scale commercial use, which is in irreconcilable contradiction with the catalytic transformation of mass-produced biomass derivatives. In this case, great efforts have been devoted to developing efficient non-noble metal catalysts for the AP-HR of FA to CPO. Hence, a series of non-noble Co [20,21], Ni [22–25], Cu [26,27], and bimetallic Ni-Fe [28], Ni-Co [29], and Cu-Co [30] catalysts were applied in FA hydrogenation to CPO in water. For instance, Hu [23] reported that the N, P co-doped carbon encapsulated Ni catalyst obtained 86.7 % yield to CPO at 403 K and found that heteroatom introduction favored reactant adsorption and provided Lewis acid sites that benefit the selectivity to CPO. Moreover, Zhu [26] applied the defects-rich nano-twin Cu catalyst in FA hydrogenation to CPO with 92 % selectivity and demonstrated that planar defects facilitated the HCP formation and then enhanced the selectivity to CPO. Recently, Cheng [22] revealed the effect of water on the AP-HR of FA and found that water acted as dual donors to provide H and O for CPO and presented in whole reaction including hydrogenation, ring opening, rearrangement, and ring re-closing. Similarly, water-mediated selectivity to CPO in FA hydrogenation was also found by Ranaware [20]. It is generally appreciated that the synergistic effect of bimetallic can achieve catalytic effects that cannot be achieved by simple superposition of single metals due to the optimization of geometric and electronic structures of bimetallic nanoparticles [31]. Specifically, Cu catalysts are favorable for the selective hydrogenation of carbonyl groups due to their strong ability to polarize the C = O bonds while leaving the C = C unreacted [32,33]. Undoubtedly, FOL is the key intermediate in the AP-HR of FA to CPO and affects the yield to CPO. Unfortunately, Cu-based catalysts present lower in comparison with some other non-noble metal catalysts. Ni catalysts show strong capability for adsorption and activation of H2, and the strong adsorption of C = C leads to low selectivity to unsaturated alcohol [34]. Nevertheless, it is attractive that Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts might possess the advantage of promoting the hydrogenation of FA to CPO in water with high selectivity and activity. Herein, a series of Cu-Ni/SiO2 bimetallic catalysts with different metal ratios were prepared and applied in FA hydrogenation to FOL and CPO in different solvents. The synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni was studied by XRD, XPS, TPD, TPR, CO pulse chemisorption, Py-DRIFTS, and TEM. More importantly, the reaction mechanism was revealed by in-situ/on-line DRIFTS and DFT calculations. Under the optimum conditions, Cu3Ni1/SiO2 gives 99.9 % yield to FOL in isopropanol and 96.7 % yield to CPO in water. The low cost and high activity of Cu3Ni1/SiO2 make it a potential catalyst for the green production of FOL and CPO in industry. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Ni/SiO2 Firstly, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was added to 20 mL of ethanol, then 2 mL of aqueous ammonia solution was added and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. Subsequently, a certain amount of 0.1 M Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was added and stirred at room temperature for 24 h under ultrasonic. Then, the mixture was centrifuged and washed with ethanol repetitively, followed by drying at 353 K for 12 h to obtain the precursor of Ni/SiO2. Finally, the precursor of Ni/SiO2 was calcined at 623 K for 2 h under N2 flow and then reduced at 573 K for 2 h under H2 flow to obtain the Ni/SiO2. 2.2 Synthesis of Cu/SiO2 and CuxNi1/SiO2 (x = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) Cu/SiO2 and CuxNi1/SiO2 (x = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) were prepared by the urea deposition method. Briefly, a certain amount of 0.1 M Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and urea were dissolved in deionized water under ultrasonic, followed by adding the above prepared spherical SiO2 to the mixture, and then stirred at 363 K for 24 h under ultrasonic. Afterward, the mixture was centrifuged and washed with ethanol repetitively, followed by drying at 353 K for 12 h to obtain the precursor of Cu/SiO2. Finally, the precursor of Cu/SiO2 was calcined at 623 K for 2 h under N2 flow and then reduced at 573 K for 2 h under H2 flow to obtain the Cu/SiO2. Similarly, the preparation method of CuxNi1/SiO2 (x = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5) is similar to that of Cu/SiO2, except that the SiO2 is replaced by Ni/SiO2. The Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts (Scheme 2 ) were labelled as CuxNi1/SiO2 (x = 1, 2, 3, 4, 5), and X represents the different molar ratios of Cu/Ni. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts N2 physisorption isotherms . Figure S1 shows the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distributions of the catalysts. As seen in Figure S1 (A), all the catalysts present the typical IV-type isotherms with obvious H2-type hysteresis loop at relatively high pressure (0.8 ∼ 1.0P/P0), indicating the mesoporous structure of the catalysts. Moreover, Figure S1 (B) shows that the BJH pore size distributions of the catalysts are mainly concentrated around 3.0 nm ∼ 5.0 nm. Furthermore, the specific surface area, average pore volume, and pore size of the catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . As shown in Table 1, with the introduction of metal active components, the BET surface area and the Pore volume of the catalysts increase obviously. Especially, the Cu3Ni1/SiO2 shows the largest BET surface area (256.6 m2/g) and average pore volume (0.528 cm3/g). XRD . Figure S2 shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts. In Figure S2 (A), the broad diffraction peak around 22.0° is attributed to amorphous SiO2. For Ni/SiO2, the diffraction peak at 44.5°, 51.8°, and 76.4° belong to the refection of Ni0 lattice plane (111), (200), and (220) (JCPDS 04–0850), while the peaks at 37.2°, 43.2°, 62.8°, 75.4° are ascribed to NiO [35,36]. For Cu/SiO2, the peaks at 43.3°, 50.4°, and 74.1° are assigned to the Cu0 lattice plane (111), (200), (220) (JCPDS 04–0836), while a smaller peak around 36.5° represents the existence of Cu2O species [37–39]. More importantly, the positions of these diffraction peaks on the Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts are located between those of Cu0 and Ni0, indicating the formation of the Cu-Ni alloy [32,40–44]. Also, the (111) crystal plane of Cu-Ni alloy in Figure S2 (B) demonstrates this conclusion. In addition, as the Cu content increases, the peaks of Cu-Ni alloy shift to a lower degree. Moreover, the peak intensity of Cu-Ni alloy in the bimetallic catalyst is weaker than that of the monometallic catalyst, indicating that the appropriate Ni addition strengthens the synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni and favors the dispersion of Cu-Ni alloy nanoparticles [41,43]. Especially, when the ratio of Ni/Cu is 1:3, Cu3Ni1/SiO2 shows the broadest peaks of Cu-Ni alloy, implying the highly dispersed nanoparticles. What’s more, it is interesting to note that the peaks of NiO in the bimetallic catalyst almost disappear, indicating that the synergistic cooperation between Ni and Cu facilitates the formation of Cu-Ni alloy and favors the reduction of NiO [40,42–44]. H2-TPR and H2-TPD . Fig. 1 (A) shows the H2-TPR profile of the catalyst precursors. As seen in Fig. 1 (A), CuO/SiO2 exhibits two reduction peaks at 513 K and 533 K, respectively, the former peak is related to the reduction of CuO to Cu+, and the later peak is ascribed to the reduction of Cu+ to Cu0 [43,45]. Moreover, it can be seen from the H2-TPR curve of NiO/SiO2 that the reduction peaks at 503 K and 623 K are attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed NiO and bulk NiO, respectively [46]. Noticeably, the reduction peaks of CuO-NiO/SiO2 shift significantly toward lower temperatures, demonstrating that the reduction of both NiO and CuO is enhanced in the bimetallic catalyst. Thus, the results mean that the introduction of a second metal is conducive to the reduction of NiO and CuO and the formation of Cu-Ni alloy [40,42–44]. Besides, the reduction degree of Cu and Ni in different catalysts also confirmed the above conclusion (Table S1). In addition, compared with other bimetallic catalyst precursors, the catalyst precursor of Cu3Ni1/SiO2 has the lowest reduction temperature of CuO and NiO, the largest hydrogen consumption, and the highest Cu+ peak area, suggesting the strongest synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni, thus forming the most hydrogenation active sites [40,41,44]. However, due to the high reduction temperature of NiO, the reduction degree of the metal decreases gradually with the excessive increase of Ni content. Fig. 1 (B) shows the H2-TPD profiles of the catalysts. As seen in Fig. 1 (B), the H2 desorption peaks are divided into two regions, the low-temperature region (323 ∼ 473 K) is ascribed to the physically adsorbed H2 on the surface of catalysts, and the high-temperature region (523 ∼ 873 K) is attributed to the chemisorbed H2 and spillover H2 on the metallic species [43,46,47]. Notably, the H2 desorption peaks on the bimetallic catalysts shift toward lower temperature than that of the monometallic catalysts (Cu/SiO2 and Ni/SiO2), and the amounts of H2 desorbed from the bimetallic catalysts are greater than those from the monometallic catalysts, the reason may be attributed to that the synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni suppresses nanoparticles growing and enhances the reduction, thus increasing metallic surface area [43,47]. Additionally, the main desorption peak (523 ∼ 873 K) of bimetallic catalysts exhibits lower temperature and larger H2 desorption than that of Cu/SiO2, indicating that the presence of Ni promotes the adsorption of H2 at the Cu sites of the bimetallic catalysts. The fact that Cu3Ni1/SiO2 presents the lowest H2 desorption temperature and the largest H2 desorption amount, implying that it has the best nanoparticle dispersion and the most exposed metallic sites, which agrees well with the results of XRD in Figure S2 and H2-TPR in Fig. 1 (A). Unfortunately, further increment of Ni content increases H2 desorption temperature and decreases H2 desorption amount, indicating that the superabundant nickel oxide decreases the reduction degree and lowers the adsorption of H2. It has been demonstrated that H2 can be dissociated on the Ni sites in the Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts, the dissociated H atoms overflow to the adjacent Cu sites, and the weak H binding on the Cu sites can favor the desorption of H2 at lower temperatures [43]. The results further relate to the fact that Cu-Ni alloy promotes the dispersion of nanoparticles and promotes the formation of metallic species, which plays an active role in H2 adsorption and dissociation [43,46,47]. 4 XPS The surface electronic states of the metal species on the catalysts are studied by XPS and shown in Fig. 2 . In Fig. 2 (A), the high-resolution XPS spectra of Cu 2p3/2 can be deconvolved into two characteristic peaks at 935.11 eV and 932.68 eV, which are associated with Cu2+ and Cu0/+, respectively [41–43]. Moreover, in Fig. 2 (B), the peaks around 854.28 eV and 852.84 eV in the high-resolution Ni 2p3/2 XPS profile are assigned to Ni2+ and Ni0, respectively [34,40,41]. Meanwhile, the peak area of Cu0/+ and Ni0 in bimetallic catalysts is greater than that of monometallic catalysts, further suggesting that the synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni benefits CuO and NiO reduction and then forms much more hydrogenation active sites [40–44]. Noticeably, for bimetallic catalysts, the binding energy of Cu0/+ is higher than that of Cu/SiO2 (＞932.68 eV), while the binding energy of Ni0 in Ni/SiO2 presents the opposite trend (＜852.84 eV), the reason may be that the synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni causes the electron transfer from Cu to Ni, thus forming the electron-rich Ni species and the electron-deficient Cu species in the bimetallic catalysts, simultaneously proving the formation of Cu-Ni alloy [40–42,46]. More importantly, it should be noted that Cu3Ni1/SiO2 presents the largest peak ratio of Cu+/0 and Ni0 and the greatest binding energy shift, indicating that it has the strongest synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni. In addition, the binding energies and peak area ratios of metal species are listed in Table S2, which are compatible with the results of XRD in Figure S2 and H2-TPR/H2-TPD in Fig. 1. Furthermore, it is widely accepted that the Cu species (Cu+ and Cu0) are more discernible in the Cu LMM Auger spectra [32,41,48]. In Fig. 2 (C), the peaks at 913.72 eV and 917.23 eV are ascribed to Cu+ and Cu0, respectively [32,41,48]. In Cu LMM, the changing trend of kinetic energy is opposite to that of binding energy [49], and the kinetic energy of Cu0 in bimetallic catalysts moves to a lower direction in comparison with that of monometallic catalysts [50]. More importantly, with the increment of Ni content, the value of Cu+/(Cu++Cu0) (Table S2) and the shift of the Cu LMM increase first and then decrease. Particularly, Cu3Ni1/SiO2 possesses much more electron-deficient Cu+, thus forming more Lewis acid sites to adsorb C = O, and hence facilitates the adsorption of polarized C = O via the lone pair electrons of the oxygen atoms [32,33]. CO pulse chemisorption and in-situ CO-FTIR . CO pulse chemisorption in Fig. 3 (A) is carried out to quantitatively the active adsorption sites, analyze metal surface area, and metal dispersion of the catalysts [51], and the results are summarized in Table 1. Fig. 3 (A) shows the pulsed chemisorption traces of the catalysts at 193 K, reaching saturation around the fourth pulse. Cu3Ni1/SiO2 exhibits the largest number of active adsorption sites, the largest metal surface area (20.8 m2/g), and the highest metal dispersion (55.7 %), which are consistent with the results of XRD (Figure S2), H2-TPR/H2-TPD (Fig. 1), and XPS (Fig. 2). To further study the interaction between Cu and Ni, in-situ FTIR of CO adsorption on the catalyst was performed and their corresponding maps are shown in Fig. 3 (B). Generally, the band below 2000 cm−1 is ascribed to the multi-coordinated adsorption of CO, while the band above 2000 cm−1 is attributed to the linear adsorption of CO [52,53]. In Fig. 3 (B), it can be observed that all catalysts present two adsorption peaks at 2171 cm−1 and 2120 cm−1, attributing to the physical adsorption of CO [54,55]. Moreover, for the Ni/SiO2, two peaks appear at 2049 cm−1 and 1886 cm−1, which belong to the linear and multi-coordinated adsorption of CO on Ni0 sites, respectively [52]. Noticeably, for the Cu/SiO2, the linear adsorption of CO partially overlaps with the physical adsorption of CO, the band at 2098 cm−1 fitted by the overlapping peaks belongs to the linear adsorption of CO on Cu+ sites, since the adsorption enthalpy of CO on Cu2+ and Cu0 sites is lower than Cu+, thus CO preferentially adsorbs on Cu+ sites [55]. Interestingly, compared with Cu/SiO2 and Ni/SiO2, in-situ CO-FTIR spectra of Cu3Ni1/SiO2 show that the linear adsorption peak on Cu+ sites blue-shifts to 2120 cm−1, the linear adsorption peak at Ni0 sites. red-shifts to 2032 cm−1, the multi-coordinated adsorption peak on Ni0 sites disappears, and the intensity of these peaks increase significantly, the reason may be that the strong synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni causes the electron transfer from Cu to Ni and thus increases the electron density of Ni species, which favors electron back-donation from the d orbitals of Ni to the π* orbital of CO, thereby strengthening Ni-CO and weakening the C≡O bond [11,52]. Meanwhile, the reduced electron density of Cu species weakens Cu+–CO, resulting in a blue shift of the CO vibration peak [53]. Furthermore, the formed Cu-Ni alloy promotes the high dispersion of Cu-Ni nanoparticles and thus inhibits the multi-coordinated adsorption of CO, and the increased linear adsorption amount of CO also confirms the significant increase of Cu+ and Ni0 species in the Cu3Ni1/SiO2 [56], which accords well with the results of XRD (Figure S2), H2-TPR/H2-TPD (Fig. 1), and XPS (Fig. 2). 5 NH3/CO2-TPD It is generally appreciated that the conversion of FA to CPO contains acid-catalyzed furan ring-opening reactions [20–30], and thus NH3-TPD (Fig. 4 (A)) and CO2-TPD (Fig. 4 (B)) were carried out to gain further understanding of the essential acid-base properties of the catalysts, and the results are shown in Table 2 . In Fig. 4 (A), the NH3 desorption peaks can be divided into three regions: 323 ∼ 473 K (weak acidic sites), 473 ∼ 673 K (medium-strength acidic sites), and above 673 K (strong acidic sites), respectively [27,43,46]. It is noteworthy that the weak and medium acidic strength of bimetallic catalysts are higher than that of monometallic catalysts, and these desorption peaks shift to higher temperatures, suggesting that the strength and amount of acidic sites are enhanced. The result may be attributed to the fact that the synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni favors Lewis acidic sites of Cu+ species formation [27,32,33]. As shown in Table 2, Cu3Ni1/SiO2 presents the highest total acidic sites (384.3 μmol/g) caused by the largest amount of Cu+ species (H2-TPR in Fig. 1, XPS in Fig. 2, and in-situ CO-FTIR in Fig. 3). However, further increment of Ni content leads to a decrease of acidic sites due to the decrement of the proportion of Cu+ species. Correspondingly, the CO2-TPD profiles of the catalysts in Fig. 4 (B) show the main CO2 desorption peak at the region of 573 ∼ 773 K, which may be assigned to the desorption of CO2 from Cu-O or Ni-O sites [57,58], and Cu3Ni1/SiO2 presents the lowest CO2 desorption temperature and intensity, indicating the smallest amount of total basics sites. Py-DRIFTS . Py-DRIFTS in Fig. 5 was performed to further distinguish the type of surface acidic sites on the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5 (A), the bands at 1448 cm−1 and 1608 cm−1 are assigned to pyridine adsorbed on strong Lewis acid sites (SL), and the band at 1577 cm−1 is ascribed to the weak Lewis acid sites (WL). Moreover, the band at 1538 cm−1 ascribes to protonated pyridine adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites (B) and the band at 1485 cm−1 corresponds to the overlap of L and B [20,43,59]. Interestingly, the bimetallic catalysts exhibit higher peak intensity of Lewis acidic sites (SL and WL) than that of monometallic catalysts, suggesting a higher amount of Lewis acidic sites in bimetallic catalysts, further demonstrating that the synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni is conducive to Lewis acidic sites of Cu+ species formation [27,32,33]. As can be seen in Table 2, Cu3Ni1/SiO2 possesses the strongest Lewis acid and the lowest B/L ratio (0.051), which favors the efficient activation of C = O in furfural [32,33]. Additionally, Figure S3 shows the effect of temperature on the Py-DRIFTS spectra of Cu3Ni1/SiO2. When the temperature increases from 303 K to 423 K, the strength of Lewis acid sites is still prominent, inferring that stronger Lewis acid sites exist on Cu3Ni1/SiO2, which can strongly interact with pyridine molecules [60]. Besides, it is widely accepted that the cooperation between Lewis acid sites and water plays a very important role in promoting the AP-HR of FA to CPO [20,22,61,62]. Ranaware demonstrated that water, as the solvent and reactant simultaneously, can be dissociated into hydroxyl groups on Lewis acid sites and participate in the hydrogenation-rearrangement of FA to CPO as Brønsted acid sites [20]. Therefore, to further investigate the acidity change of Cu3Ni1/SiO2 in different solvents, Cu3Ni1/SiO2 pretreated with isopropyl alcohol (IPA) and water were investigated by in-situ infrared pyridine adsorption (Py-in-situ DRIFTS) in Fig. 5 (B). As seen in Fig. 5 (B), compared with the untreated Cu3Ni1/SiO2, IPA-pretreated Cu3Ni1/SiO2 shows no obvious change in the peak intensity of the pyridine adsorption on L and B acid sites. However, for the water-pretreated Cu3Ni1/SiO2, the peak intensity of the B acid sites increases obviously, the reason may be that the strong interaction between Lewis acid sites and water causes the formation of abundant water-derived hydroxyl functional groups on the surface of Cu3Ni1/SiO2, which play a key role in the further rearrangement of FA to CPO [20,22,61,62]. SEM and TEM . Figure S4 shows the SEM images of the catalysts. As shown in Figure S4, the SiO2 remains spherical shape after loading the metal active components. Moreover, in comparison with Cu/SiO2 and Ni/SiO2, Cu3Ni1/SiO2 exhibits relatively loose spherical structure. In addition, TEM images of the catalysts are shown in Figure S5. It can be seen that the morphology of the catalysts does not change, but the dispersion of the nanoparticles is obviously different. As shown in Figure S5 (a) and (g), monometallic Cu/SiO2 and Ni/SiO2 appear obvious nanoparticles sintering, with an average nanoparticle size of 15.82 nm and 13.53 nm, respectively. Clearly, the bimetallic catalysts exhibit better nanoparticle dispersion than monometallic catalysts, and the average nanoparticle size decreases significantly with the introduction of Ni, suggesting that synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni prevents the aggregation of Cu nanoparticles and favors their dispersion [41,63]. In particular, Cu3Ni1/SiO2 shows the best dispersion of metal nanoparticles with an average particle size of 2.74 nm, which is close to the XRD broadening result in Table 1. Besides, Fig. 6 shows the HRTEM and HAADF-STEM images of the catalysts. The d TEM-spacings of 0.208 nm and 0.203 nm of Cu/SiO2 and Ni/SiO2 present in the magnification HRTEM images are ascribed to Cu (111) and Ni (111) planes [32,40,63]. Moreover, the d TEM-spacing of 0.248 nm is attributed to Cu2O (111) [32,63], suggesting the presence of Cu+. Notably, the d TEM-spacing of 0.206 nm located between Cu (111) and Ni (111) planes on Cu3Ni1/SiO2 confirms the formation of Cu-Ni alloys [32,43,63], which agrees well with the results of XRD in Figure S2, XPS in Fig. 2, and in-situ CO-FTIR in Fig. 3. What’s more, the HAADF-STEM and elemental mapping images of Cu3Ni1/SiO2 (Fig. 6 (d-h)) reveal that Cu and Ni metallic phases are evenly distributed. Moreover, the elemental line scan (Fig. 6 (i)) shows that the signals of Cu and Ni appear in the same position, further verifying the formation of Cu-Ni alloy. 6 ICP-OES The contents of Cu and Ni in the catalysts were analyzed by ICP-OES, and the results are summarized in Table 1. Theoretically, the calculated value of the total metal contents in the catalyst was about 30 wt%. As shown in Table 1, the actual mass fractions of Cu and Ni for the monometallic catalysts are close to the theoretically calculated values. Moreover, the theoretically calculated value of the Cu and Ni mass ratio is generally consistent with the measured values, demonstrating the successful synthesis of the bimetallic catalysts with different ratios. 6.1 Catalytic performance The catalytic performances over different catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 (A), bimetallic catalysts show better results than monometallic catalysts, since the synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni is conducive to the formation of CuNi alloys, thus promoting CuO and NiO reduction and forming much more metallic species (Cu0/+ and Ni0). Moreover, FA conversion and the selectivity to FOL increase firstly and then decrease with increasing the molar ratio of Cu/Ni, and Cu3Ni1/SiO2 gives the best catalytic performance (99.9 % yield to FOL). The above characterization results indicate that Cu3Ni1/SiO2 shows the strongest CuNi alloy effects, the most exposed metallic species, the highest dispersion of nanoparticles, and the largest proportion of Cu+ species (Lewis acid sites). Besides, the effects of reaction conditions (temperature, H2 pressure, time, catalyst dosage, and solvents) on FA hydrogenation to FOL over Cu3Ni1/SiO2 are investigated and the results are shown in Fig. 7 (B), (C), and (D) and Figures S6 (A) and (B), respectively. In Fig. 7 (B), as the reaction temperature increases from 313 K to 333 K, the FA conversion and selectivity to FOL are significantly improved, and the yield to FOL reaches ∼ 99.9 %. However, when the reaction temperature further increases from 333 K to 353 K, the selectivity to FOL decreases obviously, and the excessive hydrogenation product THFOL appears. What’s more, as seen in Fig. 7 (C), the FA conversion and yield to FOL gradually increase as the H2 pressure increases from 1.0 MPa to 2.0 MPa. Then the FOL selectivity decreases for further increasing the pressure to 3.0 MPa. Fig. 7 (C) shows the influence of reaction time on product distribution. After 3 h of reaction, the yield to FOL reaches ∼ 99.9 %. Figure S6 (A) illustrates that catalyst dosage presents similar effects as the above conditions and the best catalyst dosage ratio is 5:1. More importantly, the effects of solvents on product distribution are shown in Figure S6 (B). When the less polar toluene is used as the solvent, the FA conversion is only 65.3 %, probably due to the poor solubility of H2 in toluene. Meanwhile, when the high polarity of H2O is used as the solvent, FA is almost converted, but with a low selectivity to FOL, since the strong polar solvent promotes the hydro-deoxygenation reaction. Noticeably, when alcohols act as solvents, a higher yield to FOL can be obtained, especially isopropanol (IPA). Additionally, Fig. 8 (A) illustrates the effects of Cu/Ni molar ratio on FA hydrogenation to CPO. Specifically, the FA conversions over bimetallic catalysts (>90.0 %) are much higher than those over the Cu/SiO2 and Ni/SiO2. Meanwhile, the FA conversion and the selectivity to CPO increase firstly and then decrease with an increase of Ni/Cu molar ratio from 1:5 to 1:1, and their TOFCPO also gradually change (Table S1). Obviously, the catalytic performance of bimetallic catalysts is better than that of monometallic catalysts in the AP-HR of FA to CPO. Among bimetallic CuNi catalysts, Cu3Ni1/SiO2 achieves the highest yield of 96.7 % to CPO and the highest TOFCPO of 110.9 h−1. Moreover, as the amount of Ni introduction increases, the selectivity to THFOL increases obviously, suggesting that Ni prefers the hydrogenation of the furan ring. Additionally, the effects of reaction conditions such as temperature, H2 pressure, time, H2O/IPA ratio, and additives on product distribution are illustrated in Fig. 8 (B), (C), (D), (E), and (F), respectively. As shown in Fig. 8 (B), reaction temperature plays an important role in the production of CPO. At 393 K, the FA conversion is up to 98 %, while the selectivity to CPO is only 78 %. It is worthwhile to note that as the reaction temperature increases from 393 K to 413 K, the selectivity to CPO increases significantly, suggesting that a higher reaction temperature (413 K) favors the FA conversion to CPO via hydrogenation, hydrogenolysis, and rearrangement [20,27,50]. The reason may be related to that higher temperature boosts the dissociation of water to give H species, thus promoting the FOL ring open and rearrangement [20,22]. Unfortunately, further increasing the reaction temperature causes the formation of much more over-hydrogenation product cyclopentanol (CPL) and by-products. Similarly, as can be seen from Fig. 8 (C) and (D), with the increase of initial H2 pressure and reaction time, the FA conversion and the selectivity to CPO increase first and then decrease, and the optimal H2 pressure and reaction time are 3.0 MPa and 2 h. More importantly, to further understand the role of water in the AP-HR of FA to CPO, the effect of H2O/IPA ratio on product distribution is investigated. As shown in Fig. 8 (E), when the H2O/IPA ratio is 3:7, the main products are FOL and THFOL. Noticeably, as the H2O/IPA ratio increases, the selectivity to CPO increases significantly, suggesting that water as a reactant plays a decisive role in the AP-HR of FA to CPO [20,22,61,62]. Moreover, Fig. 8 (F) shows the influence of additives (AcOH and Pyridine) on product distribution. It can be seen that trace amounts of AcOH (0.01 g) as an additive can slightly improve the selectivity to CPO, while further increasing the amount of AcOH causes further hydrogenation of CPO. Unfortunately, the selectivity to CPO sharply decreases from 96.7 % to 56 % with the addition of pyridine (0.01 g), the reason may be that the basic molecule pyridine can be strongly adsorbed on acidic sites [28,50]. Besides, considering that FOL is an important intermediate during the AP-HR of FA to CPO, the hydrogenation of FOL as the substrate was investigated in Figure S7. It is noted that the FOL conversion and the selectivity to CPO increase when the Ni/Cu molar ratio changes from 1:5 to 1:1, especially Cu3Ni1/SiO2 gives the highest yield to CPO (95.6 %) at 393 K (Figure S7 (A)). As expected, the yield to CPO decreases as the reaction temperature increases. It was noteworthy that with the temperature increasing, FOL conversion increases significantly, while the selectivity to CPO firstly increases and then decreases (Figure S7 (B)). When the reaction temperature is 393 K, Cu3Ni1/SiO2 presents the best catalytic performance. Moreover, the effects of H2 pressure (Figure S7 (C)) and reaction time (Figure S7 (D)) on FOL hydrogenation to CPO were also investigated. Similarly, as the hydrogen pressure and reaction time increase, the yield to CPO increases firstly and then decreases, and the optimal H2 pressure and reaction time are 3.0 MPa and 2 h. Furthermore, Kinetic course of the FA hydrogenation to FOL and CPO over Cu3Ni1/SiO2, Cu/SiO2, and Ni/SiO2 in different solvents are illustrated in Figures S8 and S9, and the results are in good agreement with the results in Figures 7, 8, and Fig. S7. After that, the reusability of Cu3Ni1/SiO2 is shown in Figure S10. Encouragingly, after the fifth cycle, the catalytic performance of Cu3Ni1/SiO2 is almost the same as that of the fresh catalyst. The FA conversion and the selectivity to CPO show a slight decrease in the following sixth cycle, indicating the good reusability of Cu3Ni1/SiO2. The XRD (Figure S11 (A)) pattern and TEM (Figure S11 (B)) image of the used Cu3Ni1/SiO2 show that metal nanoparticles exhibit a slight sintering. Moreover, the Ni and Cu XPS spectra (Figures S11 (C), (D), and (F)) of the used Cu3Ni1/SiO2 show a slight loss of the Ni0, Cu0/+, and Cu+ species. Also, the Py-DRIFTS (Figure S11 (F)) spectrum of the used Cu3Ni1/SiO2 illustrates that the peak intensity of Lewis acid sites decreases. Hence, the above characterizations may explain the decrease of the catalytic performance in the sixth cycle of Cu3Ni1/SiO2. Also, Table S3 summarizes the catalytic performance of the recent catalysts used to catalyze the hydrogenation of FA to CPO. Compared with these catalysts, Cu3Ni1/SiO2 presents the advantages of simple process, high yield, low cost, and relatively mild conditions to realize the economic feasibility of the CPO production from FA. 6.2 Reaction mechanism As mentioned above, the reaction routes and product distribution of FA hydrogenation are related to different solvents [20,22,25,28]. It is generally accepted that FA is more prone to form CPO in water because water is an indispensable reactant for achieving the AP-HR of FA to CPO [20,22,61,62]. In this work, the main products were FOL, THFOL, CPO, and CPL, together with trace amounts of cyclopentenone (CPEO). Thus, a plausible reaction mechanism for FA hydrogenation in aqueous phase is proposed. As shown in Scheme 3 , FA (1) firstly converted to FOL (2) by hydrogenation of the C = O group, and then the formed FOL reacts with H+ ions dissociated from water to break the C-O bond and form Intermediate Ⅰ (3). Next, Intermediate Ⅰ (3) undergoes the nucleophilic attack of H2O to the C5 ring, followed by ring rearrangement to form unstable HCP (4). Subsequently, HCP converts to CPEO (5) via hydro-deoxygenation. Finally, CPO (6) is obtained by further hydrogenation of CPEO (5). From Scheme 3, the formation of HCP is a critical step to obtain CPO [17,22,26,30,62]. These intermediates such as HCP and CPEO were verified by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS, Figure S12). To gain insight into the mechanism for FA conversion, the adsorption of FA and FOL and the reaction process of FA hydrogenation to FOL and CPO were studied using in-situ/on-line DRIFTS, and the relevant spectra are shown in Figure S13 and Fig. 9 . Figure S13 (A) shows the in-situ DRIFTS of FA adsorption on different catalysts. For the vapor FA (curve a), the bands at 1678 cm−1, 1572 cm−1, and 1486 cm−1 are ascribed to ν(C = O), ν(furan ring), and ν(C = C) stretching vibration, respectively [61,64]. Moreover, compared with vapor FA, the peak intensity of ν(furan ring) increases on Ni/SiO2, probably due to Ni activation of the furan ring of furfural [65]. As to Cu/SiO2 and Cu3Ni1/SiO2, the peak intensity of ν(C = O) increases obviously in comparison with vapor FA, especially for Cu3Ni1/SiO2, indicating that Cu3Ni1/SiO2 possesses the most Cu+ Lewis acid sites. More importantly, the ν(C = O) on Cu3Ni1/SiO2 exhibits the strongest red-shift, suggesting that Cu3Ni1/SiO2 preferentially adsorbs and activates C = O rather than furan rings due to the formation of abundant Cu+ [20,64]. Furthermore, in-situ DRIFTS of FA adsorption on IPA-pretreated and water-pretreated Cu3Ni1/SiO2 were investigated to explore the effects of solvents on the adsorption of FA in Figure S13 (A). The FA adsorption spectrum on IPA-pretreated Cu3Ni1/SiO2 is almost the same as Cu3Ni1/SiO2. It is worth noting that water-pretreated Cu3Ni1/SiO2 exhibits the strongest ν(C = O) adsorption and the maximum red-shift, the reason may be that more acid sites are formed on the Cu3Ni1/SiO2 surface after water treatment. More importantly, the ν(furan ring) on water-pretreated Cu3Ni1/SiO2 shows a significant red-shift and its peak intensity increases obviously, suggesting that the adsorption ability of furan rings on water-pretreated Cu3Ni1/SiO2 is enhanced, hence favors furan ring activation and further rearrangement to CPO. The results agree well with the Py-in-situ DRIFTS in Fig. 5 (B). Additionally, Figures S13 (B) and (C) show the in-situ DRIFTS spectra of FA hydrogenation to FOL over Cu3Ni1/SiO2 and Cu/SiO2, respectively. In Figure S13 (B), for Cu3Ni1/SiO2, as the reaction proceeds (0 ∼ 10 min), the peak of ν(C = O) (1662 cm−1) decreases rapidly and the peak of ν(C-OH) (1085 cm−1) increases obviously. As to Cu/SiO2, Figure S13 (C) shows that the peak intensity of ν(C = O) and ν(C-OH) do not change significantly. The results indicate that Cu3Ni1/SiO2 preferentially realizes the FA hydrogenation to FOL in comparison with Cu/SiO2. As shown in Scheme 3, FOL is the key intermediate, and the selective adsorption and activation of the intermediate functional groups can affect the reaction path and the distribution of hydrogenation products. Therefore, in-situ DRIFTS spectra of FOL adsorption on water-pretreated catalysts are investigated and shown in Fig. 9 (A). Compared with vapor FOL, the peak intensity of ν(C = C) (1585 cm−1) increases, while the peak intensity of ν(C-OH) (1241 cm−1), ν(C-O) (1085 cm−1), and ν(C-O-C) of furan ring (1006 cm−1) decreases on water-pretreated Ni/SiO2, further indicating that Ni prefers the hydrogenation of the furan ring [65]. Conversely, the peak intensity of ν(C-OH), ν(C-O), and ν(C-O-C) increases obviously on water-pretreated Cu/SiO2 and their positions appear a faint red-shift. Intriguingly, water-pretreated Cu3Ni1/SiO2 shows the strongest adsorption of ν(C-OH), ν(C-O), and ν(C-O-C) with the largest red-shift, demonstrating that the enhanced acidity on water-pretreated Cu3Ni1/SiO2 benefits the adsorption and activation of C-OH and C-O-C, hence promotes the hydrolytic furan ring opening and rearrangement to CPO [50,65]. Moreover, Figure S14 shows the in-situ DRIFTS spectra of FOL adsorption on water-pretreated Cu3Ni1/SiO2 at different temperatures. As the temperature increases, the peak intensity of these groups on FOL is significantly enhanced, indicating that higher temperature facilitates the dissociation of water to form more acid sites on the catalyst surface, thus promoting the FOL adsorption, ring opening, and rearrangement [20,65]. Additionally, Fig. 9 (B), (C), and (D) show the in-situ DRIFTS spectra and on-line DRIFTS spectra of FOL hydrogenation to CPO on the catalysts at 413 K. In Fig. 9 (B) and (C), as the reaction proceeds (0 ∼ 60 min), the peak intensity of ν(C-OH) (in FOL), ν(C-O) (in prim-alcohol), ν(C = C) (in furan ring), ν(=C–H), and ν(C-O-C) (in furan ring) decreases significantly, indicating the occurrence of acid-catalyzed furan ring opening and hydrogenation-rearrangement [50,65]. At 10 min, the newly formed peaks at 1720 cm−1 and 1110 cm−1 are attributed to ν(C = O) (in ketone) and ν(C-O) (in sec-alcohol) [26,48,60], suggesting the formation of HCP via Piancatelli rearrangement [17,22,26,30,62]. As the reaction proceeds, the peak intensity of ν(C-O) (in sec-alcohol) increases firstly and then decreases, while the peak intensity of ν(–CH2-) is consistently enhanced, indicating that HCP can be further hydro-deoxygenated to CPEO [26,48,60]. Subsequently, the peak intensity of ν(C = C) and ν(=C–H) decrease, while the peak intensity of ν(C = O) (in ketone) and ν(–CH2-) increase continuously, implying the constant formation of CPO. In addition, compared with Cu3Ni1/SiO2 (Fig. 9 (C)), Cu/SiO2 (Fig. 9 (D)) shows relatively weaker changes in the intensity of these characteristic peaks, suggesting that the AP-HR of FOL to CPO is more likely to occur on Cu3Ni1/SiO2. More importantly, the position of ν(–OH) (in water) appears a significant blue-shift, demonstrating that the cooperation between Cu+ species and water can activate the water and weaken its hydrogen bond, thus promoting its dissociation and participation in the reaction [66]. 6.3 DFT calculations To get further insight into the reaction mechanism of FA AP-HR to CPO, DFT calculations were employed to simulate the reaction process including adsorption configurations and energies of FA, FOL, CPO, H2, active H (H*), and water, as well as the reaction pathways and energy barriers of FA to CPO. Herein, Cu (111), Cu4Ni1 (111), Cu3Ni1 (111), Cu2Ni1 (111), Cu1Ni1 (111), and Ni (111) catalyst models were established and shown in Figure S15. To understand the electronic structure of Cu (111), Cu4Ni1 (111), Cu3Ni1 (111), Cu2Ni1 (111), Cu1Ni1 (111), and Ni (111) crystal surfaces, the total electron density and d-band center energies were investigated and shown in Fig. 10 and Figure S16. In Fig. 10, blue regions represent sufficient electron states, while the orange regions represent deficient electron states, respectively. Concerning Cu (111), the Cu atoms exhibit an adequate electronic state. Notably, in the case of CuxNi1 (111), the Ni atoms acquire a satisfactory electron state, indicating that Ni introduction substantially modifies the electron density distribution on CuxNi1 (111) in comparison with Cu (111), further demonstrating the notable electron transfer between Cu and Ni atoms, which is beneficial to the surface activity of the bimetallic catalyst. Moreover, it is widely accepted that the catalytic activity of the transition metals can be evaluated by d-band centers [67]. As shown in Figure S16, compared with Cu (111) and Ni (111), the positive shifting of CuxNi1 (111) d-band centers decreases obviously, especially the Cu3Ni1 (111), indicating the highest activity of the Cu3Ni1 (111), further proving that Ni modification contributes to the improvement of catalytic hydrogenation activity. Additionally, as shown in Figure S17, the adsorption configurations of H2 on the Cu (111), Ni (111), and CuxNi1 (111) crystal surfaces are obtained, corresponding to Bridge, Face-centered cubic, Hexagonal close-packed, Parallel, Top on Cu, and Top on Ni positions. Meanwhile, the corresponding calculation results of H2 adsorption on these crystal surfaces are displayed in Figure S18 and Figure S19, and the distances of the H-H bond (in Å) on these crystal surfaces are summarized in Table S4. Also, the correlating largest H2 adsorption energy relationships are: Eads (Cu3Ni1 (111))﹥Eads (Cu2Ni1 (111))﹥Eads (Cu4Ni1 (111))﹥Eads (Cu1Ni1 (111))﹥Eads (Ni (111))﹥Eads (Cu (111)), and the corresponding distance of H-H bond (in Å) on these crystal surfaces is stretched to 3.340 Å, 3.068 Å, 2.825 Å, 2.342 Å, 1.846 Å, and 1.319 Å, respectively. The results show that with the increase of Ni introduction, the H2 adsorption energy and H-H bond distance firstly increase and then decrease. Obviously, it can be observed in Figure S19 (1f) that the H2 adsorbed on Cu3Ni1 (111) at the position of Top on Ni possesses the largest H2 adsorption energy (−2.79 eV), suggesting that H2 is more prone to adsorb and dissociate on Ni sites of Cu3Ni1 (111). As displayed in Figure S20, the adsorption models of active H (H*) at the Bridge, Face-centered cubic, Hexagonal close-packed, Top on Cu, and Top on Ni positions of Cu (111), Cu4Ni1 (111), Cu3Ni1 (111), Cu2Ni1 (111), Cu1Ni1 (111), and Ni (111) crystal surfaces are established, and the lowest adsorption energy of H* on these crystal surfaces is −1.71 eV, −0.92 eV, −0.59 eV, −0.74 eV, −1.17 eV, and −1.46 eV, respectively. It is apparent that the H* adsorbed on Cu3Ni1 (111) presents the lowest adsorption energies, suggesting that the H* is more likely to desorb from Cu3Ni1 (111) surface and then enhance the hydrogenation activity. Also, it is well known that water plays an irreplaceable role in the AP-HR of FA to CPO [20,22,61,62]. Thus, the adsorption configurations of water at different positions on different crystal surfaces are obtained and shown in Figure S21, and the adsorption energy results and the O–H bond lengths (in Å) are presented in Figure S19, Figure S22, and Table S5, respectively. It is worth noting that the trend of the adsorption energy of water on different crystal surfaces is consistent with the trend of the adsorption energy of H2. Notably, in Figure S19 (2e), the water adsorbed on the Cu top position of Cu3Ni1 (111) presents the largest adsorption energy (−3.28 eV) and the longest O–H bond distance (2.840 Å), suggesting that water can be more efficiently absorbed and dissociated on Cu3Ni1 (111). Consequently, the adsorption configurations of FA on the Cu (111), Ni (111), and CuxNi1 (111) crystal surfaces in parallel and perpendicular states are shown in Figure S23, and the calculation results and C = O bond distance (in Å) are presented in Figure S24 and Table S6. As shown in Figure S24, FA adsorbed on these crystal surfaces in a parallel state can be transferred to a perpendicular state after the adsorption configurations optimization, implying that FA prefers to adsorb on the crystal surface in a perpendicular state. Moreover, it can be seen that the largest adsorption energy of FA on Cu (111), Cu4Ni1 (111), Cu3Ni1 (111), Cu2Ni1 (111), Cu1Ni1 (111), and Ni (111) crystal surfaces is −2.99 eV, −5.43 eV, −5.95 eV, −5.72 eV, −4.96 eV, and −3.96 eV, respectively. Significantly, CuxNi1 (111) crystal surfaces show a higher FA adsorption energy than that of Cu (111) and Ni (111), suggesting that the synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni favors FA adsorption and activation. Afterward, Cu3Ni1 (111) shows the largest adsorption energy of FA and the longest C = O bond distance, proving that the activation of the C = O bond is most easily achieved on Cu3Ni1 (111). Additionally, the adsorption configurations of FOL on Cu (111), Ni (111), and CuxNi1 (111) crystal surfaces in parallel and perpendicular states are shown in Figure S25, the corresponding calculation results are presented in Figure S26 and Table S7. In Figure S26, the adsorption energy of FOL on these crystal surfaces presents the following order: Eads (Ni (111))﹥Eads (Cu (111))﹥Eads (Cu1Ni1 (111))﹥Eads (Cu4Ni1 (111))﹥Eads (Cu2Ni1 (111))﹥Eads (Cu3Ni1 (111)). Especially, the Cu site of Cu3Ni1 (111) presents the lowest FOL adsorption energy (−2.32 eV) and the shortest C = O bond distance (1.614 Å), indicating that FOL can effectively desorb from Cu3Ni1 (111) and thus obtain higher selectivity to FOL. Moreover, the adsorption configurations of CPO on these crystal surfaces in parallel and perpendicular states are shown in Figure S27, the corresponding calculation results are presented in Figure S28 and Table S8. In Figure S28, the lowest adsorption energies of CPO on Cu (111), Cu4Ni1 (111), Cu3Ni1 (111), Cu2Ni1 (111), Cu1Ni1 (111), and Ni (111) crystal surfaces are −3.95 eV, −2.57 eV, −1.73 eV, −2.04 eV, −3.01 eV, and −4.38 eV, respectively. Also, the trend of the FOL adsorption energy in Figure S26 is the same as that of the CPO adsorption. Noticeably, the Cu top site of Cu3Ni1 (111) possesses the lowest CPO adsorption energy (−1.73 eV), which facilitates the desorption of CPO from Cu3Ni1 (111) and hence achieves higher selectivity to CPO. As seen in Scheme 3, FA (1) firstly converts to FOL (2) via C = O hydrogenation, then the C-O bond of FOL is cleaved on acidic sites to form oxycation intermediate (Intermediate Ⅰ (3)), and then the Intermediate Ⅰ (3) is attacked by H2O to form the key intermediate of HCP (4) via Piancatelli rearrangement, and the HCP subsequently converts to CPEO (5) through hydro-deoxygenation, followed by hydrogenation of CPEO to CPO (6). Therefore, the reaction pathway of the FA AP-HR to CPO was studied to get insights into the reaction mechanism. The calculated structures of intermediates and transition states (TS) in the AP-HR of FA to CPO on Cu (111), Cu4Ni1 (111), Cu3Ni1 (111), Cu2Ni1 (111), Cu1Ni1 (111), and Ni (111) crystal surfaces are illustrated in Fig. 11 and Figures S29-S33, respectively, and their potential energy profiles are displayed in Fig. 12 . Moreover, the corresponding bond length details and the energy barriers of FA to CPO are summarized in Table S9-S14 and Table S15, respectively. As seen in Fig. 11 and Fig. 12, the adsorbed FA (1) and two H* on Cu3Ni1 (111) surface (1a) react to produce the intermediate FOL (2) by forming the C1-O1H bond (TS (1a-2)) with an activation barrier of 25.17 Kcal⋅mol−1. Moreover, the energy barriers of TS (1a-2) on Cu (111), Cu4Ni1 (111), Cu2Ni1 (111), Cu1Ni1 (111), and Ni (111) crystal surfaces are 32.67 Kcal⋅mol−1, 28.42 Kcal⋅mol−1, 26.35 Kcal⋅mol−1, 29.88 Kcal⋅mol−1, and 34.79 Kcal⋅mol−1, respectively. The results show that FA hydrogenation to FOL is more easily realized on Cu3Ni1 (111) surface, resulting in higher selectivity to FOL, which agrees well with the results in Fig. 7 and in-situ DRIFTS in Figure S13. Afterward, the O1 atom of FOL (2) is attacked by the H+ ion and undergoes hydro-deoxygenation and rearrangement process to form Intermediate Ⅰ (3) via TS (2a-3) with an activation barrier of 73.15 Kcal⋅mol−1. In TS (2a-3), the C1-O1 bond of FOL is broken and lengthened to 2.077 Å, and the C5-O2 bond is shortened from 1.495 Å to 1.456 Å to form C5 = O2 double bond (Fig. 11 and Table S15). Also, as shown in Table S15, the energy barriers of TS (2a-3) on Cu (111), Cu4Ni1 (111), Cu2Ni1 (111), Cu1Ni1 (111), and Ni (111) crystal surfaces are 101.39 Kcal⋅mol−1, 87.59 Kcal⋅mol−1, 79.33 Kcal⋅mol−1, 92.57 Kcal⋅mol−1, and 108.21 Kcal⋅mol−1, respectively. Notably, in Fig. 12, it is apparent that TS (2a-3) presents the highest energy barrier, indicating that the conversion of FOL to Intermediate Ⅰ (3) is the rate-determining step. Significantly, Table S15 shows that Cu3Ni1 (111) presents the longest broken C1-O1 bond and the lowest TS (2a-3) energy barrier, implying that the intermediate forms more readily on Cu3Ni1 (111). Additionally, the formed Intermediate Ⅰ (3) combines with water and then undergoes Piancatelli rearrangement to form HCP (4) via TS (3–4). In TS (3–4), the C5-O3 bond is newly formed and the broken C5 = O2 bond is elongated from 1.452 Å to 2.115 Å, suggesting that Intermediate Ⅰ (3) is activated by water to break the C5 = O2 bond and form C5-O3H. The reaction energies of TS (3–4) on Cu (111), Cu4Ni1 (111), Cu3Ni1 (111), Cu2Ni1 (111), Cu1Ni1 (111), and Ni (111) crystal surfaces are 72.33 Kcal⋅mol−1, 59.27 Kcal⋅mol−1, 51.67 Kcal⋅mol−1, 56.51 Kcal⋅mol−1, 67.39 Kcal⋅mol−1, and 81.56 Kcal⋅mol−1, respectively. Similarly, Cu3Ni1 (111) presents the longest broken C5 = O2 bond and the lowest TS (3–4) energy barrier, indicating that Cu3Ni1 (111) surface is more prone to form HCP. The following step is hydro-deoxygenation of the C5-O3 bond of HCP (4) to form CPEO (5) via TS (4a-5) with a low activation barrier of 36.33 Kcal⋅mol−1, suggesting that this process happens quickly. Subsequently, the CPEO (5) continues to undergo hydrogenation to obtain CPO (6) via TS (5a-6). Noticeably, it can be observed in Fig. 12 and Table S15 that the conversion of FOL to HCP presents the largest total reaction energy, suggesting that the HCP is the key intermediate to form CPO, which is well consistent with the in-situ/on-line DRIFTS results (Fig. 9). More importantly, Cu3Ni1 (111) presents the lowest total reaction energy for the conversion of FOL to CPO (124.82 Kcal⋅mol−1), suggesting that Cu3Ni1 (111) is favorable for CPO formation, thus obtaining the highest yield to CPO. Overall, in-situ/on-line DRIFTS and DFT calculations demonstrate that HCP is the key intermediate to form CPO. More importantly, Cu3Ni1 (111) crystal surface with the lowest d-band center and the strongest electronic effects shows the highest adsorption energies of H2, H2O, and FA, the lowest adsorption energies of H*, FOL, and CPO, and the lowest energy barriers of the Piancatelli rearrangement of FOL to HCP, which are key factors in obtaining high yield to FOL and CPO. 7 Conclusion In summary, Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts with varying metal ratios were successfully prepared and applied in furfural (FA) hydrogenation to furfuryl alcohol (FOL) and cyclopentanone (CPO) in different solvents. It was found that the synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni favors the formation of CuNi alloys, thereby facilitating the reduction of CuO and NiO and resulting in larger amount of metallic species (Cu0/+ and Ni0), and promoting the formation of highly dispersed nanoparticles. Moreover, the formed Cu+ species can serve as Lewis acid sites and improve the adsorption of polarized C = O, thus markedly enhancing the selectivity to FOL. More importantly, the cooperation between Cu+ species and water can promote the AP-HR of FA to CPO. Also, in-situ/on-line DRIFTS shows that the Cu3Ni1/SiO2 preferentially adsorbs and activates C = O and prefers to form 4-hydroxy-2-cyclopentenone (HCP) which is the key intermediate to form CPO. DFT calculations agree with the in-situ/on-line DRIFTS, showing that Cu3Ni1 (111) crystal surface with the lowest d-band center and the strongest electronic effects presents the highest adsorption energies of H2, H2O, and FA, the lowest adsorption energies of H*, FOL, and CPO, and the lowest energy barriers of the Piancatelli rearrangement of FOL to HCP. Under the optimum conditions, Cu3Ni1/SiO2 gives 99.9 % yield to FOL at 333 K in isopropanol and 96.7 % yield to CPO at 413 K in water. The low cost and high activity of Cu3Ni1/SiO2 make it a potential catalyst for the green production of FOL and CPO in industry. coredata.dc:description: The selective hydrogenation of furfural derived from biomass is of significant importance in the synthesis of valuable chemical compounds. In this work, Cu-Ni bimetallic catalysts with varying metal ratios were effectively synthesized using the urea deposition method and employed in catalytic hydrogenation of furfural (FA) to furfuryl alcohol (FOL) and cyclopentanone (CPO) in different solvents. The study revealed that the synergistic interaction between Cu and Ni favors the formation of CuNi alloys, thereby facilitating the reduction of CuO and NiO and resulting in larger amount of metallic species (Cu0/+ and Ni0), and promoting the formation of highly dispersed nanoparticles. Moreover, the formed Cu+ species can serve as Lewis acid sites and improve the adsorption of polarized C = O, thus significantly enhancing the selectivity to FOL. More importantly, the cooperation between Cu+ species and water can promote the aqueous-phase hydrogenation-rearrangement (AP-HR) of FA to CPO. Also, in-situ/on-line DRIFTS shows that Cu3Ni1/SiO2 preferentially adsorbs and activates C = O and prefers to form 4-hydroxy-2-cyclopentenone (HCP), which is the key intermediate to form CPO. DFT calculations agree with the in-situ/on-line DRIFTS, showing that Cu3Ni1 (111) crystal surface with the lowest d-band center and the strongest electronic effects presents the highest adsorption energies of H2, H2O, and FA, the lowest adsorption energies of H*, FOL, and CPO, and the lowest energy barriers of Piancatelli rearrangement of FOL to HCP. Under the optimum conditions, Cu3Ni1/SiO2 gives 99.9 % yield to FOL at 333 K in isopropanol and 96.7 % yield to CPO at 413 K in water. The low cost and high activity of Cu3Ni1/SiO2 make it a potential catalyst for the green production of FOL and CPO in industry.
